Based on your preference for a deeper and more insightful movie, I'd recommend "Young Frankenstein" and "End of Watch".

"Young Frankenstein" is a comedic yet thought-provoking film that explores the nature of life and identity through the lens of science and humor. It stars talented actors like Gene Wilder and Madeline Kahn.

"End of Watch", on the other hand, delves into the complexities of friendship, morality, and societal issues as it follows two police officers navigating the gritty streets of LA. With performances by Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Peña, this film offers a raw and intense portrayal of their experiences. Enjoy!

I'd highly recommend watching "Schindler's List" (1993). This powerful film takes us back to World War II, focusing on Oskar Schindler, a businessman who risked his life to save hundreds of Jewish workers from the Holocaust. Liam Neeson delivers an outstanding performance as Schindler in this Oscar-winning film that will surely leave a lasting impression.

If you're interested in a different perspective on the 1950s, "Radio Days" (1987) by Woody Allen might be the perfect choice. It offers a nostalgic look at radio's golden age through the eyes of an ordinary family, featuring a memorable cast including Diane Keaton, Julie Kavner, and Danny Aiello.

If you're keen on exploring a unique blend of comedy and politics, "American Dreamz" (2006) might be up your alley.
